election_record.label: Pennsylvania 1820 Electoral College

overview.note: Melchoir Rahm died on October 31, 1820. "All vacancies occasioned by death or otherwise, in the electoral college, are filled by the legislature." The Franklin Repository (Chambersburg, PA). November 14, 1820.

"Mr. MacFarland of Montgomery, having deserted the republicans at the late state election, was discarded from the democratic electoral ticket. The Press made a great noise on the subject, and retained the name of Mr. MacFarland on his ticket, urging his partizans to vote for that gentleman." Andrew Gilkeson was selected to fill John MacFarland's space on the republican ticket. The Franklin Gazette (Philadelphia, PA). November 4, 1820.
The Susquehanna Democrat (Wilkes-Barre, PA) lists Andrew Gilkeson as the only candidate from the "Officeholder's Ticket." November 10, 1820.

"The Clintonian ticket, manufactured at the self-styled 'anti-slavery' meeting of federalists and factionists in this city, received a meagre vote even here...Though the federalists did not numerously turn out to vote, Mr. Monroe and Mr. Tompkins, the republican candidates, are indebted to them for no support in this district. The votes given to those distinguished gentlemen were almost exclusively given by republicans. In truth, the federal party, with a few liberal and honorable exceptions, are as hostile to the republican administration as they ever were, and only required a little more time and a glimmering prospect of success to have made a bold push against President Monroe." The Franklin Gazette (Philadelphia, PA). November 4, 1820.

"The only opposition [to the Monroe ticket], worthy of notice, was in the city of Philadelphia, where an "anti-slavery ticket" (got up we presume merely to try the sincerity of those who harped so much about General Hiester's vote on the supplement to the abolition law) received 793 votes." The Franklin Repository (Chambersburg, PA). November 14, 1820.
"Several of the [Clintonian] candidates are friendly to Mr. Monroe, and declined previous to the election." The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA). November 4, 1820.
The ticket pledged to De Witt Clinton was little publicized and organized relatively late in the campaign.

Very few counties reported votes for individual electors. Most only reported the votes for the tickets as a whole. In these cases, the votes listed for the first candidates on each ticket represent the votes for the tickets as a whole.

sub_unit.name: Bedford
sub_unit.note: The American Sentinel (Philadelphia, PA), November 14, reports 459 for the Monroe ticket.

sub_unit.name: Dauphin
sub_unit.note: The American Sentinel (Philadelphia, PA), November 14, reports 715 votes for the Monroe ticket.

sub_unit.name: Lancaster
sub_unit.note: The Richmond Enquirer (Richmond, VA), the American Republican, the Lancaster Journal (Lancaster, PA), The Union, and the American Sentinel all report 1507 votes for the Monroe ticket.
The Northampton Correspondent reports 1548 votes for the Monroe ticket.
The Franklin Gazette (Philadelphia, PA) reports 1506 votes for the Monroe ticket.

sub_unit.name: Luzerne
sub_unit.note: Andrew Gilkeson received 38 votes as Andrew Gilkinson.
Gabriel Hiester, Sr. received 38 votes as Gabriel Hiester, Jr.
Nathan B. Boileau received 1 vote as Nathaniel B. Boileau.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: In Philadelphia City, several of the tickets erroneously listed the name "James S. Sanderson" instead of "James P. Sanderson". As a result, the returns show 382 votes for James P. Sanderson and 874 votes for James S. Sanderson. However, all 1256 of these votes were intended for the same candidate. The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA). November 4, 1820.
"Many of the citizens [of Philadelphia City], opposed to the extension of slavery, declined voting either of the tickets." Poulson's American Daily Advertiser (Philadelphia, PA). November 4, 1820.
The Democratic Press (Philadelphia, PA) reports 1238 votes for James Kerr.

sub_unit.name: High Street
sub_unit.note: The Kentucky Reporter, November 20, reports 45 votes for the Clintonian ticket.

sub_unit.name: Philadelphia
sub_unit.note: In Philadelphia County, several of the tickets erroneously listed the name "James S. Sanderson" instead of "James P. Sanderson". As a result, the returns show 143 votes for James P. Sanderson and 1574 votes for James S. Sanderson. However, all 1717 of these votes were intended for the same candidate.

sub_unit.name: Blockley
sub_unit.note: The Republican Star and General Advertiser (Easton, MD), November 14, and the Daily National Intelligencer, November 7, report 16 votes for the Clintonian ticket.

sub_unit.name: Washington
sub_unit.note: The Reporter, November 13, reports 633 votes for William Clinghan.

sub_unit.name: Westmoreland
sub_unit.note: The Franklin Gazette (Philadelphia, PA) reports 85 votes for John MacFarland.
